avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 90 to 150 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2500 m.

Above approximately 2300 m: In particular on steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes numerous large to very large dry and moist avalanches are to be expected. From starting zones that have retained some snow the avalanches can in many cases reach an unusually long way and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes.

The weather will be mostly sunny. The weather conditions will bring about a substantial rise in the danger of moist and wet avalanches as the day progresses.

It is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs: From starting zones at higher altitudes large and, in many cases, very large avalanches are to be expected.

snowpackStructure.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong southeasterly wind, large wind slabs formed above the tree line. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack at elevated altitudes.

Low and intermediate altitudes as well as south and east facing slopes: Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a moist old snowpack.
The sleet gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m.

tendency.highlights: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the snowpack in particular at intermediate altitudes.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Tuesday above approximately 2300 m.
Above approximately 2300 m and on very steep slopes more large to very large natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack, especially on steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes.
As before the avalanches can reach an unusually long way from high-altitude starting zones.
Below approximately 2500 m: Numerous moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

The conditions are dangerous for backcountry touring.
avalancheActivity.highlights: At high altitude a high avalanche danger will persist.

snowpackStructure.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong easterly wind, sometimes deep wind slabs formed at high altitude.
Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.
Below approximately 2600 m: The sleet gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.
The covering of new snow is wet.

tendency.highlights: The weather conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the snowpack in particular at intermediate altitudes.

avalancheActivity.comment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2200 m.
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the northeasterly wind can be released easily or naturally above approximately 2300 m.
In particular on steep slopes numerous medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The sleet gave rise to extreme moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack at elevated altitudes.

Below approximately 2000 m a little snow is lying.
